statement: The work is well-motivated to address the hard-to-acquire tactile perception by using vision for dexterous robotic hands.
The proposed method simply combines existing techniques such as extracting point cloud from RGBD camera and using simulator to simulate grasping, lacking novelty.
The texture extraction method in the pseudo-tactile information extraction component overlaps significantly with existing work.
It is unclear how the conditions to classify points as texture features work in the texture feature extraction framework using thresholds for Y-component normal vectors and grayscale variance.
The role of simulation using NVIDIA Isaac Sim in the research plan is not clear, particularly regarding how the pseudo-tactile information is used for closed-loop control.

It is unclear how the related work on pseudo-haptics, which is associated with giving humans touch sensory feedback, is connected to the 'pseudo-tactile' approach for analyzing surface tactile properties of objects.
How the tactile information from the point cloud is used in contact localization is not clearly explained in the methodology.
The precision and resolution of the ground truth measurement for contact localization evaluation is not specified in the experimental design.
How the texture feature points are used once they're determined by thresholding is not explained in the pseudo-tactile information extraction component.
There lacks definitions of the 'grayscale variance' and 'Y-component' parameters used in the texture feature extraction algorithm.
The research plan focuses on quasi-static grasping rather than extending to more dynamic manipulation tasks to explore whether the extracted object features can be leveraged for complicated tasks.
There is no measurement of how good the quality of the generated pseudo-tactile signals are, both quantitatively and qualitatively.
It is unclear how accurate real-world contact positions are acquired for comparison with simulated 3D fingertip coordinates in the evaluation methodology.

Depth images generated by Intel RealSense D435 can be very noisy, thus the estimation of surface normal vectors can be very biased, but the research plan does not address how to deal with this problem.

The dataset includes objects with glass material, but depth images generated from RealSense Camera on transparent objects are problematic, and it's unclear how accurate point cloud information can be obtained under these circumstances.
